He is a member of both the [[Revolutionary Socialists (Egypt)|Revolutionary Socialists]] and the Center for Socialist Studies in [[Cairo]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://mrzine.monthlyreview.org/2011/hamalawy080211.html | title=Revolution 2.0: Interview with Hossam el-Hamalawy | publisher=MRZine | date=8 February 2011 | accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref>

'''Hossam el-Hamalawy''' ({{lang-ar|Ø­Ø³Ø§Ù Ø§ÙØ­ÙÙØ§ÙÙ}}) is an [[Egyptian]] [[journalist]], [[blogger]] and [[socialist]] activist. He is a member of both the [[Revolutionary Socialists (Egypt)|Revolutionary Socialists]] and the Center for Socialist Studies in [[Cairo]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://mrzine.monthlyreview.org/2011/hamalawy080211.html | title=Revolution 2.0: Interview with Hossam el-Hamalawy | publisher=MRZine | date=8 February 2011 | accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref>
He is a graduate of the [[American University in Cairo]], where he was detained and [[torture]]d by the [[State Security Investigations Service]] (SSI), with the institution's complicity in 2000.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/9286/Egypt/Politics-/Students-of-Egypts-American-University-question-it.aspx | title=Students of Egypt's American University question its ties to Mubarak's regime | publisher=Ahram Online | date=7 April 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> After the [[Egyptian Revolution 2011|Egyptian Revolution]] of 2011, el-Hamalawy criticized the newly appointed [[Ministry of Justice (Egypt)|Justice Minister]] Mohamed Abdel Aziz el-Gendy, for his ties to the former [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]], in relation to the freezing of assets of the ousted dictator.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/egypt-says-us-dragging-its-feet-on-freezing-mubarak-assets/2011/03/28/AFdCA35B_story.html | title=Egypt says U.S. dragging its feet on freezing Mubarak assets | publisher=The Washington Post | date=30 March 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref>
He is a graduate of the [[American University in Cairo]], where he was detained and [[torture]]d by the [[State Security Investigations Service]] (SSI), with the institution's complicity in 2000.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/9286/Egypt/Politics-/Students-of-Egypts-American-University-question-it.aspx | title=Students of Egypt's American University question its ties to Mubarak's regime | publisher=Ahram Online | date=7 April 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> After the [[Egyptian Revolution 2011|Egyptian Revolution]] of 2011, el-Hamalawy criticized the newly appointed [[Ministry of Justice (Egypt)|Justice Minister]] Mohamed Abdel Aziz el-Gendy, for his ties to the former [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]], in relation to the freezing of assets of the ousted dictator.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/egypt-says-us-dragging-its-feet-on-freezing-mubarak-assets/2011/03/28/AFdCA35B_story.html | title=Egypt says U.S. dragging its feet on freezing Mubarak assets | publisher=The Washington Post | date=30 March 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref>
